dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Tesla's remote-controlled ice cream trucks just navigated Manhattan's streets without a driver—that's a world first.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Tesla's remote-controlled ice cream trucks just navigated Manhattan's streets without a driver-that's a world first.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Starsky Robotics, a San Francisco startup trying to commercialize automated truck technology, said its the first company to test an unmanned 18-wheeler on a stretch of U.S. highwayand it so by combining an onboard self-driving system with a remote operator standing by to guide the vehicle when necessary. Testing of a Volvo semi-truck loaded up with cameras and radar began June 16 on a 9.4-mile stretch of the Florida Turnpike in Orlando, connected to a Starsky teleoperations center in Jacksonville, said CEO and cofounder Stefan Seltz-Axmacher.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they did it with an average speed of 15 miles an hour, which is, uh, pretty impressive for such a dense area.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they did it with an average speed of fifteen miles an hour, which is, uh, pretty impressive for such a dense area.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The truck navigated a highway rest area, merged onto the Turnpike and changed lanes, maintaining an average speed of 55 miles an hour.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they specifically mentioned frozen pizzas and ice cream as the goods being transported safely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they specifically mentioned frozen pizzas and ice cream as the goods being transported safely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the initial run wasnt a revenue-generating one, probably the next time you hear about it it will be hauling a load.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting how they're focusing only on perishable products, unlike Waymo or those scooter startups that are trying to do everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting how they're focusing only on perishable products, unlike Waymo or those scooter startups that are trying to do everything.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and they're using microwave sensors and radar instead of just cameras, which Musk says lets them move faster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and they're using microwave sensors and radar instead of just cameras, which Musk says lets them move faster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Testing of a Volvo semi-truck loaded up with cameras and radar began June 16 on a 9.4-mile stretch of the Florida Turnpike in Orlando, connected to a Starsky teleoperations center in Jacksonville, said CEO and cofounder Stefan Seltz-Axmacher.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, the remote operator is basically just watching a map and has a video-game-style steering wheel to take over if needed?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, the remote operator is basically just watching a map and has a video-game-style steering wheel to take over if needed?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The remote operator sits in front of a bank of video monitors that show everything the trucks cameras see. Theres a small, video-game-style steering wheel, accelerator and brake pedals and other controls that let operators take over when necessary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it seems like their system is designed for simplicity, especially in easy driving conditions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it seems like their system is designed for simplicity, especially in easy driving conditions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its easiest and most effective in places where driving is most difficult, Seltz-Axmacher said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they're not even trying to tackle highways yet because of all the pedestrians and complex intersections in cities.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're not even trying to tackle highways yet because of all the pedestrians and complex intersections in cities.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Starsky Robotics, a San Francisco startup trying to commercialize automated truck technology, said its the first company to test an unmanned 18-wheeler on a stretch of U.S. highwayand it so by combining an onboard self-driving system with a remote operator standing by to guide the vehicle when necessary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, other companies like TuSimple are canceling test programs—they had one delivering hot dogs from New York to Chicago.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, other companies like TuSimple are canceling test programs-they had one delivering hot dogs from New York to Chicago.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: TuSimple just completed a pilot program with the U.S. Postal Service hauling mail from Phoenix to Dallas in its automated semis; and Volvo Trucks this month formed an autonomous tech alliance with Nvidia to create robotic commercial vehicles.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's wild. But Tesla's making this a secondary service, right? They mentioned earning around $200,000 a year from initial investments.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild. But Tesla's making this a secondary service, right? They mentioned earning around two hundred thousand dollars a year from initial investments.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a result, its now generating revenue that helps fund ongoing development of its high-tech trucks, in addition to the $22 million its raised so far from initial investment rounds.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Musk said they're bringing in about $20,000 a month, but he didn't say if they're planning more funds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Musk said they're bringing in about twenty thousand dollars a month, but he didn't say if they're planning more funds.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Were in the neighborhood of half a million dollars a month, Seltz-Axmacher said, declining to comment on whether Starsky has additional fundraising plans.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they only have two employees and twenty non-automated trucks? That seems really lean for such an ambitious project.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they only have two employees and twenty non-automated trucks? That seems really lean for such an ambitious project.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company has a fleet of 40 trucks, both automated and non-automated, and 80 employees, about half of whom are truck drivers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It does, but maybe that's part of their strategy—keep it small, focus on what works, and scale later.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does, but maybe that's part of their strategy-keep it small, focus on what works, and scale later.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Still, the big challenge now is generating revenue, like Musk told the Detroit Free Press.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, the big challenge now is generating revenue, like Musk told the Detroit Free Press.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a result, its now generating revenue that helps fund ongoing development of its high-tech trucks, in addition to the $22 million its raised so far from initial investment rounds. Were in the neighborhood of half a million dollars a month, Seltz-Axmacher said, declining to comment on whether Starsky has additional fundraising plans.

HostA: Right, and they specifically mentioned frozen pizzas and ice cream as the goods being transported safely.
HostB: It's interesting how they're focusing only on perishable products, unlike Waymo or those scooter startups that are trying to do everything.
HostA: Exactly, and they’re using microwave sensors and radar instead of just cameras, which Musk says lets them move faster.
HostB: But wait, the remote operator is basically just watching a map and has a video-game-style steering wheel to take over if needed?
HostA: Yeah, it seems like their system is designed for simplicity, especially in easy driving conditions.
HostB: And they’re not even trying to tackle highways yet because of all the pedestrians and complex intersections in cities.
HostA: Meanwhile, other companies like TuSimple are canceling test programs—they had one delivering hot dogs from New York to Chicago.
HostB: That’s wild. But Tesla’s making this a secondary service, right? They mentioned earning around $200,000 a year from initial investments.
HostA: Musk said they’re bringing in about $20,000 a month, but he didn’t say if they’re planning more funds.
HostB: And they only have two employees and twenty non-automated trucks? That seems really lean for such an ambitious project.
HostA: It does, but maybe that’s part of their strategy—keep it small, focus on what works, and scale later.
HostB: Still, the big challenge now is generating revenue, like Musk told the Detroit Free Press.
